title: Idea Development
desc: Learn to transform raw ideas into actionable business concepts.

content.title: Brainstorming Techniques
content.content:
Explore methods to generate and refine innovative ideas.
The best ideas emerge when you think freely and creatively. Use brainstorming techniques such as:

- **Mind Mapping**: Write your central theme in the middle and expand it with associations.
- **Thinking Hats**: View your problem from different perspectives (e.g., positive, critical, emotional).
- **Reverse Thinking**: Consider how you would worsen the problem, then find solutions to achieve the opposite.

content.title: Brainstorming Practice
content.content: Create a mind map for a problem you observe. Write down at least five possible ideas to solve it.

content.title: Problem Solving
content.content:
Identify real-world problems and develop solutions that add value. A problem is the starting point for every great business idea. Use the 5-Why method to find the root cause:

1. Why does the problem occur?
2. Why is it relevant?
3. Find the core cause and consider: How could your solution look?

content.title: Problem Solving Practice
content.content: Formulate the problem you want to solve in one sentence. Describe your solution idea in two sentences.

content.title: Vision and Goals
content.content:
Define a clear vision and achievable goals for your startup. Your vision gives your startup direction, and your goals make it actionable. Consider:

- **Vision**: What do you want to achieve with your startup?
- **Goals**: What concrete steps will lead you there?

content.title: Vision and Goals Practice
content.content: Formulate your startup's vision in one sentence. Write down three specific goals you aim to achieve within the next six months.

title: Product Development
desc: Build and refine your product to meet customer needs. Create an initial prototype.

content.title: Understanding Prototypes
content.content:
Create your product by developing a prototype. A prototype is a preliminary version of your product that demonstrates its core features and furthermore enables to test its functionality, design, or usability with test users. Learn how to:

- Identify essential features.
- Build a Minimum Viable Product (MVP).
- Gather early feedback by friends, family members or others to improve your design.

content.title: Key functionalities
content.content: Describe the key features of your product. Outline what your first prototype will include.

content.title: Prototype Version
content.content: Do you want to offer a physical or software-based product, or a service? Describe your product or service accurately.

content.title: Iterative Design
content.content:
Product development is an iterative process. Test your prototype, gather feedback, and refine. Use the **Build-Measure-Learn** loop:

1. Build: Develop your MVP.
2. Measure: Test it with real users.
3. Learn: Improve based on feedback.

content.title: Prototype-Fidality
content.content: Are you planning a simple (low-fidelity) or detailed (high-fidelity) prototype? What form (e.g. sketch, mockup, simulation) would be useful?

content.title: Resources
content.content: What resources (time, budget, tools) do you have available to develop a prototype?

content.title: Prototype Testing
content.content: Who will test your prototype and how are you planning to reach out to these people? List your test groups in descending importancy.

content.title: Prototype Testing II
content.content: How will you ensure that your prototype enables real/accurate/reliable user feedback? e.g. time-tracking, location-setup etc.

content.title: Iterative Design Practice
content.content: List three ways you can test your prototype and gather meaningful feedback.

content.title: Customer Personas
content.content:
Understand your costumer needs and create a costumer persona. A customer persona is a fictional representation of your ideal customer. Define your target audience by:

- Demographics: Age, location, income.
- Psychographics: Interests, values, lifestyle.
- Pain Points: What problems do they face?

content.title: Costumer Problems
content.content: In one sentence, what problems or needs does the target audience have?

content.title: Customer Persona Upload
content.content: Have you already created personas or another form of user perspective? If so, please upload your file here.

content.title: Customer Persona
content.content: Describe your ideal customer as detailed as possible and well-structured. Include their demographics, psychographics, and main challenges.

content.title: Customer Journey Mapping
content.content:
Understand your customer's product experience by mapping their journey. Identify:

1. How they discover your product.
2. What steps they take to purchase or use it.
3. Pain points along the way.

content.title: Costumer Journey Mapping Upload
content.content: Have you already created a customer journey map? If so, please upload your file here.

content.title: Customer Journey Creation
content.content: Create a short customer journey for your product. Highlight one potential obstacle and how youâ€™ll address it.

title: Competitive Analysis
desc: Identify your competitors and define your unique advantage.

content.title: Identifying Competitors
content.content:
Competitive analysis is the process of identifying and evaluating your competitors. It helps you uncover gaps in the market, refine your value proposition, and develop strategies to differentiate your business. By analyzing the competition, you gain insights into industry trends, customer expectations, and potential opportunities, enabling you to make informed decisions and position your company for success. Competitive analysis is a foundational step for anyone entering the market. Competitors can be direct (same product) or indirect (solving the same problem differently). Analyze their:

- Products or services.
- Strengths and weaknesses.
- Pricing and market positioning.

content.title: Competitor Analysis Practice
content.content: List at least three competitors and one strength and weakness for each.

content.title: Unique Selling Proposition (USP)
content.content: Your USP is what sets you apart. It answers the question: Why should customers choose you over others?

content.title: USP Practice
content.content: Write one sentence describing your USP. What makes your product unique? Why should customers choose your offering? (e.g., price, quality, innovation)

content.title: Solution Combination
content.content: Could you combine your idea with existing approaches or technologies to improve it?

title: Marketing & Customer Relationships
desc: Learn to build a brand and engage with your audience.

content.title: Building Your Brand
content.content: A strong marketing strategy is essential for anyone entering the founding market because it bridges the gap between your product and your customers. It ensures that your message reaches the right people, through the right channels, at the right time. Without a clear plan, you risk wasting resources on efforts that don't connect with your target audience or drive results. A well-crafted strategy helps you prioritize the channels your customers use most, engage them effectively, and build trust. It also allows you to measure success and adjust your approach as needed.

content.title: Brand Practice
content.content: Write a tagline for your brand that captures its essence in one sentence.

content.title: Engaging Your Audience
content.content:
Effective customer relationships are built on trust and communication. Use:

- Social Media: Connect where your audience spends time.
- Email Campaigns or Communities: Keep them informed and engaged.
- Personalization: Make your communication relevant. - Offline marketing: Visit entrepreneur fairs, distribute flyers at optimal locations etc.

content.title: Audience Engagement
content.content: List at least three ways you will interact with your audience. Be specific about the channels and message types. Will the interactions be personal or automated?

content.title: Audience Engagement Priority
content.content: Which channels will you prioritize, and why? You can focus on which channels are used most frequently by your target group.
What steps will you take to acquire and retain customers long-term?
